parse.title: List of the deadliest firefighter disasters in the United States

text.*:
Below is a list of the deadliest firefighter disasters in the United States, in which more than five firefighters died.

Contents

  • 1 List
  • 2 Notes
    • 2.1 Footnotes
    • 2.2 Citations

List[edit]

Rank Event Date Fatalities Coordinates Reference
1 September 11 attacks September 11, 2001 343 40°42′46.8″N 74°0′48.6″W﻿ / ﻿40.713000°N 74.013500°W﻿ / 40.713000; -74.013500 [1][2]
2 Great Fire of 1910 August 22, 1910 78[N 1] 47°25′34″N 116°6′13″W﻿ / ﻿47.42611°N 116.10361°W﻿ / 47.42611; -116.10361 [3]
3 1933 Griffith Park Fire October 3, 1933 29 34°8′32.66″N 118°17′36.28″W﻿ / ﻿34.1424056°N 118.2934111°W﻿ / 34.1424056; -118.2934111 [2]
4 Texas City disaster April 16, 1947 27 29°22′39″N 94°53′29″W﻿ / ﻿29.37750°N 94.89139°W﻿ / 29.37750; -94.89139 [1][2]
5 Chicago Union Stock Yards fire December 22, 1910 21 41°49′8.31″N 87°39′40.08″W﻿ / ﻿41.8189750°N 87.6611333°W﻿ / 41.8189750; -87.6611333 [1][2]
6 McKee refinery fire July 29, 1956 19 35°57′21.28″N 101°53′11.49″W﻿ / ﻿35.9559111°N 101.8865250°W﻿ / 35.9559111; -101.8865250 [1][2]
Yarnell Hill Fire June 30, 2013 19 34°14′47.84″N 112°45′20.94″W﻿ / ﻿34.2466222°N 112.7558167°W﻿ / 34.2466222; -112.7558167 [2]
8 Blackwater fire of 1937 August 21, 1937 15 44°24′43″N 109°44′30″W﻿ / ﻿44.41194°N 109.74167°W﻿ / 44.41194; -109.74167 [4]
Rattlesnake Fire July 9, 1953 15 39°39′19.05″N 122°38′9.67″W﻿ / ﻿39.6552917°N 122.6360194°W﻿ / 39.6552917; -122.6360194 [1][2]
10 South Canyon Fire July 6, 1994 14 39°34′26.48″N 107°25′36.82″W﻿ / ﻿39.5740222°N 107.4268944°W﻿ / 39.5740222; -107.4268944 [1][2]
11 Strand Theatre fire March 10, 1941 13 42°4′58.40″N 71°1′9.58″W﻿ / ﻿42.0828889°N 71.0193278°W﻿ / 42.0828889; -71.0193278 [1][2]
Mann Gulch fire August 4, 1949 13 46°52′46.56″N 111°54′17.64″W﻿ / ﻿46.8796000°N 111.9049000°W﻿ / 46.8796000; -111.9049000 [1][2]
Friedlander Leather Remnants Factory fire December 21, 1910 13 39°58′5.50″N 75°8′29.35″W﻿ / ﻿39.9681944°N 75.1414861°W﻿ / 39.9681944; -75.1414861 [1]
14 Kingman explosion July 5, 1973 12 35°12′54.10″N 114°1′48.95″W﻿ / ﻿35.2150278°N 114.0302639°W﻿ / 35.2150278; -114.0302639 [1]
23rd Street Fire October 16, 1966 12 40°44′27.39″N 73°59′20.01″W﻿ / ﻿40.7409417°N 73.9888917°W﻿ / 40.7409417; -73.9888917 [1]
16 Inaja Fire November 25, 1956 11 33°5′54″N 116°39′50″W﻿ / ﻿33.09833°N 116.66389°W﻿ / 33.09833; -116.66389 [5]
17 West Fertilizer Company explosion April 17, 2013 10 31°48′58″N 97°05′17″W﻿ / ﻿31.816°N 97.088°W﻿ / 31.816; -97.088 [6]
18 Charleston Sofa Super Store fire June 18, 2007 9 40°44′27.39″N 73°59′20.01″W﻿ / ﻿40.7409417°N 73.9888917°W﻿ / 40.7409417; -73.9888917 [7]
Hotel Vendome fire June 17, 1972 9 42°21′4.55″N 71°4′43.09″W﻿ / ﻿42.3512639°N 71.0786361°W﻿ / 42.3512639; -71.0786361 [1][2]
Collins Block Fire (Syracuse, NY) February 3, 1939 9 43°3′4.79″N 76°9′12.92″W﻿ / ﻿43.0513306°N 76.1535889°W﻿ / 43.0513306; -76.1535889 [8]
21 Great Boston Fire of 1872 November 9, 1872 8 42°21′13.75″N 71°3′30.80″W﻿ / ﻿42.3538194°N 71.0585556°W﻿ / 42.3538194; -71.0585556 [9]
1975 Philadelphia Gulf refinery fire August 17, 1975 8 39°54′7″N 75°12′17″W﻿ / ﻿39.90194°N 75.20472°W﻿ / 39.90194; -75.20472 [10]
Jackson Pyrotechnic Explosion (Chester, PA) February 17, 1882 8 39°50′46″N 75°21′24″W﻿ / ﻿39.84611°N 75.35667°W﻿ / 39.84611; -75.35667 [11]
24 Waldbaum's supermarket fire August 2, 1978 6 40°35′33.93″N 73°57′0.48″W﻿ / ﻿40.5927583°N 73.9501333°W﻿ / 40.5927583; -73.9501333 [12]
Kansas City ammonium nitrate explosion November 29, 1988 6 39°50′47.98″N 94°34′22.49″W﻿ / ﻿39.8466611°N 94.5729139°W﻿ / 39.8466611; -94.5729139 [13]
Worcester Cold Storage and Warehouse Co. fire December 3, 1999 6 42°15′36.23″N 71°47′34.17″W﻿ / ﻿42.2600639°N 71.7928250°W﻿ / 42.2600639; -71.7928250 [1]

Notes[edit]

Map all coordinates using: OpenStreetMap 
Download coordinates as: KML · GPX

Footnotes[edit]

  1. ^ Another source says that there were 86 deaths, but this seems to count almost all of the civilians as well.[2]
